componenttext: And I know you announced the Citation Ten, can you comment? It looks like that's a relatively modest upgrade? The cabin -- well, it's longer, it's not wider. Do you have any other -- can you comment at all on other new products that we might look for over the next 12 months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let me first say that the -- I mean, the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior, as well as the winglets and things like that, has actual
componenttext: Sure. Well, let me first say that the -- I mean, the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior, as well as the winglets and things like that, has actually been -- it's a pretty major makeover to the aircraft and customer response has been very strong to it. So I mean they're pretty impressed with it. But the issue -- that I can also address around other new products is clearly, we have a number of things in the pipeline. There are other pretty significant refreshes, as well as some clean-sheet aircraft, and we'll be announcing those kind of sort of as we kind of go from show to show here over the next 18 months to two years as these programs are getting closer to launch. And we're confident that it's the right time in terms of market receptivity to announce it. So the Ten, we have not done an upgrade to that program really almost ever. So it was really time to do it, and that's why that's the first one that we've announced out of the gate. But clearly, there are others that are in there and we'll make those announcements as the time is appropriate at ensuing shows.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit
componenttext: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit '10 to prepare yourself for whatever '11 is, you're probably not prepared to give us '11 guidance here on the call. But trying to think about loading the factory here at year end and the throughput in the factory and what that implies for next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. So we have made -- as you probably saw the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago. And what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventory, the rate at which we've been building thi
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. So we have made -- as you probably saw the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago. And what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventory, the rate at which we've been building this year, what we forecast in terms of deliveries for the fourth quarter this year, as well as our kind of first estimate is what we think the deliveries will look like for 2011 and adjust the production rate, so that we think we have the right rate now, moving through the balance of the year. Now this is the first time we've told you this, right? I mean, we've done this before. But as I said earlier, I think the reality of given what happened in sort of that May, June time frame, at least up through now we basically have kind of slid our forecast out around six to nine months in terms of what we think the recovery cycle looks like. And so those adjustments we made and production rates and staffing aligned with that. In terms of your first part of your question is, what do we expect in terms of fourth quarter deliveries? We're not putting exact number out there, but it will certainly be dramatically higher than what you saw in the third quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter, even if you didn't take stuff to final production? I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip. Is that how you get
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter, even if you didn't take stuff to final production? I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip. Is that how you get the bump in Q4?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. It's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, it's whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So we ba
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. It's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, it's whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So we basically, we done a slow down. The rate in terms of the tag [ph] time, if you will, of what we move various models to the factory out. So we've slowed down as opposed to saying we're going to build them out and then stop. So I mean, we never, as you know, have perfect alignment in terms of sales to manufacturing core because fourth quarter is usually our stronger and you got to kind of build into that. So there's not an exact number. It really is sitting in whip. It's not I'd say, hitters, we've built as many airplanes and sold as many airplanes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year, perhaps if we lock it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?
componenttext: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year, perhaps if we lock it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff, and obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way, which is we for 2010, we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis poi
componenttext: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff, and obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way, which is we for 2010, we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis point change in discount rate impacts our expense number by about $26 million and a 50 basis point change in rate of return impacts our expense number by about $20 million. Now there are lots of other factors that go into it in terms of comp rates over time and other things, but I think kind of that gives you a sense of order of magnitude of the sensitivity of our numbers at least. And we'll do that work as we move into year end, and we'll give you kind of a specific guidance on it when we give the 2011 guidance.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a point of clarification on that, separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed that 12/31/09?
componenttext: Just a point of clarification on that, separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed that 12/31/09?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there would have been already some, kind of because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done. There would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis, yes.
componenttext: Yes, there would have been already some, kind of because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done. There would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis, yes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations, I haven't been down in the NBAA myself, the sense I get is a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further depos
componenttext: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations, I haven't been down in the NBAA myself, the sense I get is a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further deposits that they have to make. How far of the way are we through that at this point?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been trying to work this thing out for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing, which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check on most accounts really h
componenttext: We've been trying to work this thing out for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing, which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check on most accounts really has been dropping pretty significantly, right? So most of the volume or the number of cancellations, which we have, which are really more in the first, second quarters of this year, which were some of the fleet operators things like that. I think mostly flushed their way out. So we have seen a real slowing in terms of the number of individual customers that wait until that next deposit is due and walk away from the aircraft. So are there going to be still some? Absolutely. As we do our forecast and look at our, both production rates and our sales programs, we anticipate that some of those customers where we kind of put in our book is a high-risk customer. More and more of those are actually -- we're now getting that deposit check. Whereas a year ago, the rate of those that we identified as being at risk was much higher that we're going ahead and switch into a cancellation. So are there still some? Absolutely. But the rate has really slowed down dramatically in that area.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side, could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year have been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then, specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking a
componenttext: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side, could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year have been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then, specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking about 25 deliveries and you're at four year-to-date?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206, 407 light side. I think and that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth individu
componenttext: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206, 407 light side. I think and that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth individual corporate is still slow, much like you see across the Cessna area. But we have still seen continued strength in the larger helicopters, the oil and gas markets, the emerging medical service markets, the international FMS markets have stayed pretty robust. So the way I see it, is that we'll be probably light to that number, but it will be mostly in sort of the very small, the very light helicopters. So from a margin perspective, from a revenue -- it's not going to be material. 429 specifically, we shipped four this quarter. We're a little behind where we would like to be just in terms of the time it took to get a lot of the kit certifications done and things like that. But you'll see a lot of deliveries here in the fourth quarter. We'll get to the 25 number probably not, but it's going to get pretty close. Again, the backlog is there. The people, the customers are there. So I still feel pretty good when you look at our forecast of 25 this year, 50 next year, which is kind of what our production rate was aimed at. I still think we're going to be pretty much of that 75 for the two years. And again, we'll get -- I don't think we'll get to 25, but we'll get pretty close to it this year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last one, Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilize in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?
componenttext: And last one, Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilize in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss act
componenttext: No, not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss activity. I'd say, kind of overall, we are tracking very much kind of within the framework that we've talked about in terms of adequacy of capital and cash conversion levels that kind of continue to support the overall framework of the liquidation schedule. But we haven't gone through the 2011 planning process, specifically for TFC, and a lot of a loss realization will depend on the liquidation strategy that takes place through that period.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type, if you're seeing any variances there and who's particularly responsible for this pushout b
componenttext: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type, if you're seeing any variances there and who's particularly responsible for this pushout by six to nine months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we look at the last six months, it was kind of across the board, right, when the European thing hit and the impact of the euro was I think pushed a lot of customers away, but the triple effect into the U.S. So we really saw all the market
componenttext: Well, I think as we look at the last six months, it was kind of across the board, right, when the European thing hit and the impact of the euro was I think pushed a lot of customers away, but the triple effect into the U.S. So we really saw all the markets around the world shut down pretty significantly. Latin America was an exception, that still was doing okay, and some Asia Pacific was doing okay. But it was pretty much across the board, it was not all that localized. Now as we see things coming back, I mean right now I would say we're probably getting more interest and more customer demand internationally than U.S. I think part of that is a lot of U.S. customers were sort of sitting on the sidelines saying, well, if I'm going to go, I'd like to have some certainty and understanding around things like the bonus depreciation plan and whatnot. So hopefully that will move some of these guys. We know it's already moved, a few of them, kind of off the sideline and are going ahead and proceeding. But right now, I'd have to say, we've been seeing over the last, sort of September and October time frame foreign demand coming back faster than U.S. demand.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation, given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system. How is pricing on new jet toning up?
componenttext: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation, given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system. How is pricing on new jet toning up?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And you're [ph] is still there. I mean, we're stable this quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment. But i
componenttext: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And you're [ph] is still there. I mean, we're stable this quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment. But it's deal by deal, Rob, as you can imagine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?
componenttext: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with size of
componenttext: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with size of the business. And in general, just driving base cost productivity. Our activities and things like ramping up our Mexico operation actually are going very well on both the Cessna and the Bell side. I was down there with a bunch of the team just a few weeks ago and that's ramping up very quickly. So I think we're in a pretty good position here, that as volume comes back and we need to meet some of these requirements, capacity requirements that we're going to have a better cost base than we've had in the past. The other thing I would mention, which obviously here in the quarter we did finalize negotiations with our union in Wichita. I think it was a good outcome in terms of both the company and the employees. It's a seven-year deal which is great, and let's just get that behind us and focus on just getting the job done here for the next seven years. And we feel pretty good about where it was, obviously our employees agree to take sort of more of their share of the healthcare cost on a go-forward basis. And I think in terms of economics, we all recognize where the industry is and where it's going to be here in the near term going forward and put together a financial package that in the end was acceptable to both the company and the union.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder, if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any r
componenttext: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder, if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any reasons that you're worried can be sticky through the entire cycle that could kind of cause a muted demand recovery, whether it'd be that it's just a generally do more with less environment or it's a young inventory, a young used inventory or whatever it may be?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Noah, obviously, it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers that you talk to, and I guess don't let me just -- customer by saying, a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show, folks that we -- I
componenttext: Noah, obviously, it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers that you talk to, and I guess don't let me just -- customer by saying, a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show, folks that we -- I interact with on occasional basis that are -- they are Cessna customers, right? They're flying our aircraft. And so this is kind of a core, if you will, of a customer base that does refresh their fleets on a fairly regular basis. This is what they're talking, right? The fact that they're now a year or two years, some of them going three years beyond what they would normally do in terms of refreshing and updating their aircraft. So I think these are people that are, without a doubt, going to do it. The question of the timing is obviously a little bit uncertain, but it's going to happen. The growth I think as we've talked to international customers, the desire, the demand to have business aircraft and the productivity that they're utilized for, you hear all those same things that you've always heard. I'm pleased that the politics side of it has certainly seem to have died out. People aren't afraid of, geez, why -- be viewed as a bad guy because we have corporate aircrafts. I mean, that seems to be subsiding a little bit, which is also encouraging. So I guess the bottom line, you don't hear customers talking about things or feel things out there that says that there's a fundamental change in utility or the rationale for why you have a business jet. It's all much more built around the confidence of knowing that their businesses are in a stable spot. They're going to grow, they're going to get back to the normal world. And they're going to go about their business, which includes either buying business jets or refreshing their existing fleets.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer, and we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your lat
componenttext: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer, and we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your latest internal view of what Embraer is working on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think if your NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, price levels that have been negotiated in a good market and you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for an aircraft that you're not g
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think if your NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, price levels that have been negotiated in a good market and you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for an aircraft that you're not going to turn around and sell to fractional customers until 2013, '14, '15 or so. So I think they're pretty sharp. They took advantage of a very down market and went out and try to drive a very, very aggressive campaign that probably gave them some very favorable, I would say definitely very favorable pricing and get that locked in and not have take the delivery for several years out. So I think pretty sharp on their part. Now from our perspective, I think first of all, I don't think anybody should be surprised seeing NetJets offering as part of their suite of aircraft to customers, Embraers. They've had Cessna, they've had Hawker, they've Gulfstream. So I mean, if you look at their role it's kind of a reseller of aircraft in the fractional market. It shouldn't be a surprise again if they're going to carry a pretty broad range of aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there any update on the potential and timing for a second multi-year in V-22?
componenttext: And is there any update on the potential and timing for a second multi-year in V-22?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, negotiations and discussions with the customer have already started along that exact line.
componenttext: Absolutely, negotiations and discussions with the customer have already started along that exact line.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any sense on timing?
componenttext: And any sense on timing?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the current multi-year goes out through deliveries to 2014. So I don't know exactly, Noah, what they're talking about. But I would say in the next year or so, it's probably when they want to get that definitize and nailed down.
componenttext: Well, I mean the current multi-year goes out through deliveries to 2014. So I don't know exactly, Noah, what they're talking about. But I would say in the next year or so, it's probably when they want to get that definitize and nailed down.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Skibitski from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Skibitski from SunTrust.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not sure if you said this or not, but can you quantify for us the deposit forfeiture income this quarter at Cessna versus Q2?
componenttext: Not sure if you said this or not, but can you quantify for us the deposit forfeiture income this quarter at Cessna versus Q2?

componenttextpreview: What we said is that the net of the deposit and the used valuation was a negative couple of million dollars.
componenttext: What we said is that the net of the deposit and the used valuation was a negative couple of million dollars.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about on the one-time gain in Bell? Can you quantify that and tell us what programs they were on?
componenttext: How about on the one-time gain in Bell? Can you quantify that and tell us what programs they were on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in related to the overall kind of rate structure at Bell and just benefiting on the cost front from improving performance and leveraging the volumes that are going through Bell, kind of it benefits the quarter by about a couple of hundred basis poin
componenttext: Well, in related to the overall kind of rate structure at Bell and just benefiting on the cost front from improving performance and leveraging the volumes that are going through Bell, kind of it benefits the quarter by about a couple of hundred basis points. So we typically have said Bell should be in the 11-ish percent area on kind of a run rate basis. And obviously, we were up at the 13% area for this quarter, and that 200 basis points was kind of this performance improvement.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So not necessarily one specific program?
componenttext: So not necessarily one specific program?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's really kind of across the entirety of the base.
componenttext: No, it's really kind of across the entirety of the base.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, would you mind updating us on international opportunities for ASV in Shadow? I think I saw a couple notifications this quarter, I'm just wondering if there's anything else out there in the works?
componenttext: And then, would you mind updating us on international opportunities for ASV in Shadow? I think I saw a couple notifications this quarter, I'm just wondering if there's anything else out there in the works?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there are. I mean, Shadow, we've announced a couple. There's a couple that are still in negotiations and things we're chasing after. The same with ASV, probably the most notable international which we have talked about before is the Canadian Tap D [
componenttext: Well, there are. I mean, Shadow, we've announced a couple. There's a couple that are still in negotiations and things we're chasing after. The same with ASV, probably the most notable international which we have talked about before is the Canadian Tap D [ph] (45:13) program. That decision is probably still a year or so away, but there are also a number of other international that we haven't talked about yet, which are still sort of in the negotiation phase, which we're hopeful we would get close here on the next six month or so.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following on that Bell question, and then moving on to D&I, same kind of question with Systems. The longer-term margin there, kind of ticked down as you guys would have expected and maybe a little bit more than we would have expected in the quarter.
componenttext: Just following on that Bell question, and then moving on to D&I, same kind of question with Systems. The longer-term margin there, kind of ticked down as you guys would have expected and maybe a little bit more than we would have expected in the quarter. What is kind of a more normal kind of longer-term margin we can think of at the Defense business?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I still think the Systems business is one, Steve, that we've talked about being kind of in that 11% sort of range. I think we're still -- we still feel like that's about where it's going to be. The margin rates didn't tick down. Now when we talk abo
componenttext: Well, I still think the Systems business is one, Steve, that we've talked about being kind of in that 11% sort of range. I think we're still -- we still feel like that's about where it's going to be. The margin rates didn't tick down. Now when we talk about the fact that we did have two big chunks of business in both the ASVs and the UAVs that were very high margin businesses. We got renegotiated as you would expect and that's kind of what brought us down to those margin rates that we are -- where we are now. I think there was a little bit of a challenge in the quarters because the nature of these SFW contracts, because there's some quarters we're going to have a big sale and associated margins, other quarters where you'll probably going to have zero on SFW just because of how the lot acceptance works out. But I would say that, I think those are the kind, we don't feel differently about those margin rates than the previous guidance that we gave you, and I think we'll hang in that area.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the longer term kind of normalized margin for Bell and D&I both kind of in that low double digit range?
componenttext: So the longer term kind of normalized margin for Bell and D&I both kind of in that low double digit range?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. The only thing that has changed, Steve, that they are putting some more pressure on those numbers, and obviously we're doing other things to try to make it up. What we talked about a little bit earlier, these pension headwinds are tough in terms
componenttext: Exactly. The only thing that has changed, Steve, that they are putting some more pressure on those numbers, and obviously we're doing other things to try to make it up. What we talked about a little bit earlier, these pension headwinds are tough in terms of both earnings and obviously cash contributions ultimately we'll need to make.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would those margins be down in 2011?
componenttext: Would those margins be down in 2011?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There will be more pressure on the pension side, and so the issue for us, of course, is the challenge of trying to go drive other means of productivity to try to compensate for them, but they are pressure points for sure.
componenttext: There will be more pressure on the pension side, and so the issue for us, of course, is the challenge of trying to go drive other means of productivity to try to compensate for them, but they are pressure points for sure.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on Cessna, you had a real kind of a drying up of activity in the summer. Do you feel the market is still that sensitive? So that if the euro moves like it did back then or if we had another little gyration here in the macro environment, are
componenttext: And then just on Cessna, you had a real kind of a drying up of activity in the summer. Do you feel the market is still that sensitive? So that if the euro moves like it did back then or if we had another little gyration here in the macro environment, are people still sensitive? Do you feel like, I mean, so for every 10% to 15% move in the S&P 500, do we push out another six to nine months? Or have people kind of come to a resolution on how comfortable they feel in their financial situation that, that was kind of the last bit of pressure on the mentality of the customer? What's your sense there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, I still think this has an awful lot to do with confidence. And I think what happened, coming out of the spring, was there was a lack of confidence in the recovery. And when that happens, people, consumers and businesses kind of quit spending money.
componenttext: Steve, I still think this has an awful lot to do with confidence. And I think what happened, coming out of the spring, was there was a lack of confidence in the recovery. And when that happens, people, consumers and businesses kind of quit spending money. In other words, just airplanes, right? It was any big ticket, capital investments. And I think we saw that across most of industry, certainly in the U.S. and around most of the world. So I don't think we're immune to that. I think people have gotten -- it appears people have gotten a little more comfortable that the recovery stumbled, but it didn't go into the so-called double dip and that's now bringing a little bit of confidence back on that people can move on. But I think if there's another, if you have another European debt crisis, if you have something of that magnitude, I mean I think there's no doubt our industry is still susceptible to those kinds of things, derailing the economic recovery and more specifically, the business jet recovery.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the margin at Cessna, would you guys expect a relatively significant snap back next year? Actually, you've kind of worked your way through the overproduction of this year. How do we think about the Cessna margin for next year?
componenttext: Just on the margin at Cessna, would you guys expect a relatively significant snap back next year? Actually, you've kind of worked your way through the overproduction of this year. How do we think about the Cessna margin for next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Steve, it's all going to be based on what kind of volumes we get out there, right? We still personally feel that we will see better volumes in 2011 than 2010. I mean, I'm sure you read all the various pundits and folks that are kind of well o
componenttext: Well, again, Steve, it's all going to be based on what kind of volumes we get out there, right? We still personally feel that we will see better volumes in 2011 than 2010. I mean, I'm sure you read all the various pundits and folks that are kind of well over the map as to was '10 the trough or is '11 the trough. And look, everybody is guessing, right? I mean, our guess and our sense to talking to customers and whatnot is that we're still expecting to have higher 2011 deliveries than 2010. And obviously, that will translate into better margin rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a couple more biz [business] jet questions, sorry about belaboring this stuff. I was down at NBAA, as well as probably a bunch of my peers. You really did see a tangible difference between what's going on in the, what's called the Large Jet se
componenttext: Scott, just a couple more biz [business] jet questions, sorry about belaboring this stuff. I was down at NBAA, as well as probably a bunch of my peers. You really did see a tangible difference between what's going on in the, what's called the Large Jet segment and then kind of the mid and light. So kind of my two questions are, one, why do you think that this? What's peculiar about the mids and lights that they're just not being as robust as the large? And then two, the Columbus came, it went, if Cessna were to have a product in that space, I mean, in your view is that the good form of diversification, given how you're really seeing some different market dynamics between the different size segment?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first one, I would say, Ron, I mean there's no question that the dynamics out there for the long-haul, big, large-cabin jet market has come back faster than the light to mid-size. And I think you're talking about some different dynamics here in
componenttext: Well, the first one, I would say, Ron, I mean there's no question that the dynamics out there for the long-haul, big, large-cabin jet market has come back faster than the light to mid-size. And I think you're talking about some different dynamics here in terms of who those buyers are. Are they very large corporations or very, very high net worth individuals, families and such that, that tend to be the customer of that segment. Now the reality is, for the light to mid-size jet market, we do have obviously some fleet operations in pretty big companies. But the bulk of our customers are small, mid-size business people and high net worth individual, not somebody that's the billionaire set. So I think the confidence in that community and that little buyer is more economically sensitive than the multi-billionaire or the huge, multi-national corporation. So I think that's just going to light the world we're living in right now is that our typical buyer is more economically sensitive than the real big cabin guys. So that's where it is, it's business confidence factor comes in, in terms of getting our customers confident to go spend $6 million, $8 million, $15 million, $20 million as opposed to being up there in the $50 million, $60 million kind of transaction that you see on the large cabin guys. And I don't know why that would change, right? I mean, the light to mid will come back when our customer set feels more confidence.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then how about from a product portfolio point of view, I mean down the road, eventually, I mean is it a place Cessna should go to larger and larger aircraft?
componenttext: Then how about from a product portfolio point of view, I mean down the road, eventually, I mean is it a place Cessna should go to larger and larger aircraft?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the notion to come back, I'm sorry, your question on the Columbus side is that we do have -- if you look at our customer set, that customer set is principally more of a regional customer, right, where there's domestic U.S., domestic Eur
componenttext: Well, I think that the notion to come back, I'm sorry, your question on the Columbus side is that we do have -- if you look at our customer set, that customer set is principally more of a regional customer, right, where there's domestic U.S., domestic Europe, Latin American regions. But that customer does have a need to do some international longer-haul travel. And that's where we were, the Columbus was aimed. So are we thinking about -- we should be competing with G550s and globals? No, that's outside of I think what is traditionally our customer set. The Columbus, which we would certainly like to go back to at some point, when the market conditions are right and the light, mid-world has stabilized is a nice add-on in terms of taking care of that customer base, because we do have a significant number of them that do have some international needs, longer-haul needs. And we'd like to stay on the Cessna family as opposed to needing going over to a big Bombardier or a big Gulfstream product.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just one last question, again on the biz jet market. How much of a factor has the availability of financing and financing terms and changing financing terms been in terms of a negative headwind in terms of people finalizing orders?
componenttext: And then maybe just one last question, again on the biz jet market. How much of a factor has the availability of financing and financing terms and changing financing terms been in terms of a negative headwind in terms of people finalizing orders?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a big headwind for a while, but I would say that things have been certainly loosening up. I mean, we've had credit availability for people. We've seen some of the other larger guys historically financing in the biz jet world, are coming back
componenttext: Well, it was a big headwind for a while, but I would say that things have been certainly loosening up. I mean, we've had credit availability for people. We've seen some of the other larger guys historically financing in the biz jet world, are coming back into it. The money is clearly available. There is a desire and a need for higher levels of down payment and looking to credit. But I think it's starting to loosen up and it's not as big as an issue as it once was.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One was on the cost structure within Cessna, I guess how you're thinking about the difference between the sort of permanent-fixed cost reduction from the migration of production? And then secondly, how much of your cost reduction's related to your six to
componenttext: One was on the cost structure within Cessna, I guess how you're thinking about the difference between the sort of permanent-fixed cost reduction from the migration of production? And then secondly, how much of your cost reduction's related to your six to nine month push out in terms of the business jet delivery's recovery? And then secondly, as well just on the Industrial business, you've had very high incremental margins there because of a steep revenue bounce back of a fairly low cost base. I guess, how you're thinking about incremental margins in Industrial exiting this year in terms of adding on capacity or raising R&D and how those affect the incrementals?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if I go backward through those, I would say that, first of all, on the Industrial side, that margin leverage that we've seeing associated with the volume, as we think about 2011 and those markets continuing to recover, I think we can continue to gen
componenttext: Well, if I go backward through those, I would say that, first of all, on the Industrial side, that margin leverage that we've seeing associated with the volume, as we think about 2011 and those markets continuing to recover, I think we can continue to generate good leverage on those margins. We're certainly, even though revenue and volume has come back, it's still nowhere near back to where it was historically. So in terms of capacity to produce, we're not in a point where we have to start thinking about making any kind of significant capital investments to support further ramp in those businesses. I mean, some tooling here and there, I mean there's obviously some capital, but there's certainly no reason to think about a need to invest a lot of capital in those businesses as they continue to grow because they're still well below the levels at which they historically have seen. At Cessna, the cost, I mean you certainly have a fixed-base cost, let's say in the Wichita in terms of facilities and capability. I think as volume returns, that we can effectively utilize that capacity. I think we have a union contract and a cost base that will allow us to be very competitive in terms of aircraft completions and customizing in interiors and delivery and things like that. But as we talked about before, we still believe and are continuing to restructure in terms of where a lot of the sub-level fabrication and assembly goes along. And that's been our strategy with Mexico, where we have made some significant investments and continue to do that to make sure that we have capacity in that region at a cost that we think would need us to be for us to be competitive going forward. So there's kind of blend here of making sure you're effectively utilizing what you have in place in Wichita, but also expanding capacity in those places, where we know we have to have a lower cost labor base.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttextpreview: Here's a non-Cessna question for you. It appears that the Marine Corps is rejiggerring the makeup of their helicopter squadrons? And if you do the arithmetic, it sounds like maybe they're going to come up short some H-1s. Have they come to you? Or do you
componenttext: Here's a non-Cessna question for you. It appears that the Marine Corps is rejiggerring the makeup of their helicopter squadrons? And if you do the arithmetic, it sounds like maybe they're going to come up short some H-1s. Have they come to you? Or do you expect to talk to them about revising that contract higher?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, we're in conversations with the Marine Aviation folks on a virtually daily basis. I want to be careful to comment, specifically about your question, because I haven't had a discussion with them with respect to overall number chang
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, we're in conversations with the Marine Aviation folks on a virtually daily basis. I want to be careful to comment, specifically about your question, because I haven't had a discussion with them with respect to overall number changes. But there are regular discussions around how many utility versus how many Super Cobras. So as they are always looking out, their deployment schedules and what to make up for those squadrons are, how they operate, those are discussions that we have all the time with them. So obviously, any time they want to add additional aircraft is certainly fine with us, and we're trying to make sure we're doing the right things in terms of the cost per unit to help allow them to do it. We know they always love to have more helicopters. But obviously, they have their own budgetary issues that they got to be careful about it. But sure, we'll work with them in terms of both the mix and the makeup of them and the overall total number.

componenttextpreview: Pretty modest really, because there's some modest changes to tooling because the fuselage stretch, but the wing is virtually identical. Obviously, there's some minor modifications in the structure with the winglets. There's no tooling change on the engine
componenttext: Pretty modest really, because there's some modest changes to tooling because the fuselage stretch, but the wing is virtually identical. Obviously, there's some minor modifications in the structure with the winglets. There's no tooling change on the engines. It's a redesign on the part of Rolls-Royce for the fan, which gives us some better thrust and better efficiencies, but does not impact final assembly in terms of tooling. And then, of course, the cockpit, that adaptation is mostly fabrication work in cable and harnessing. So there's a lot of work, but it's not a capital-intensive change.

componenttext: Yes, I mean it's going to increase kind of it will depend ultimately on kind of what these calculations look like. But it's going to be up in the $200 million, $300 million-type level. Now obviously, a lot of this gets impacted by -- we're in a very, very low rate environment, right? And so kind of all of this stuff needs to ultimately be looked at in the context of both kind of whatever the rate environment is when you're setting these numbers and then expectations over time. And so for all of these to carry forward into the future, you would have to assume that the same rate environment was going to be maintained into the future, which I think most people would probably think is unlikely, but it certainly will impact the near-term calculations.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
