componenttext: So at Cessna, can you tell us were the forfeitures offset by used aircraft losses? And was the R&D up from the second quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cai, we had a little bit higher residual value write-off than we had deposit forfeitures because the cancellation rates have been down. So we didn't have a lot that went into the forfeitures, but we did have some adjustments across the whole balance of po
componenttext: Cai, we had a little bit higher residual value write-off than we had deposit forfeitures because the cancellation rates have been down. So we didn't have a lot that went into the forfeitures, but we did have some adjustments across the whole balance of portfolio in terms of used aircraft that we did some residual write-downs. But it netted, Cai, over a few million dollars. It's not a big number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I know you announced the Citation Ten. Can you comment? It looks like that's a relatively modest upgrade? The cabin, while it's longer, it's not wider. Do you have any other -- can you comment at all on other new products that we might look for over t
componenttext: And I know you announced the Citation Ten. Can you comment? It looks like that's a relatively modest upgrade? The cabin, while it's longer, it's not wider. Do you have any other -- can you comment at all on other new products that we might look for over the next 12 months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let me first say that the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior as well as the winglets, and things like that, has actually been -- it's
componenttext: Sure. Well, let me first say that the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior as well as the winglets, and things like that, has actually been -- it's a pretty major makeover to the aircraft and customer response has been very strong to it. So I mean they're pretty impressed with it. But the issue that I can also address around other new products is clearly we have a number of things in the pipeline. There are other pretty significant refreshes, as well as some clean-sheet aircraft. And we'll be announcing those sort of as we kind of go from show to show here over the next 18 months to two years as these programs are getting closer to launch and we're confident that it's the right time in terms of market receptivity to announce it. So the Ten, we have not done an upgrade to that program really almost ever. So it was really time to do it, and that's why that's the first one that we've announced out of the gate. But clearly, there are others that are in there and we'll make those announcements as the time is appropriate at ensuing shows.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit
componenttext: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit '10 to prepare yourself for whatever '11 is. You're probably not prepared to give us '11 guidance here on the call. But trying to think about loading the factory here at year end and the throughput in the factory and what that implies for next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. So we have made, as you probably saw, the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago. And what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventories, the rate at which we've been building th
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. So we have made, as you probably saw, the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago. And what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventories, the rate at which we've been building this year, what we forecast in terms of deliveries for the fourth quarter this year, as well as our kind of first estimate as to what we think the deliveries will look like for 2011 and adjusting the production rate so that we think we have the right rate now moving through the balance of the year. Now this is the first time we've told you this, right? I mean, we've done this before. But as I said earlier, I think the reality of given what happened in sort of that May, June time frame, at least up through now we basically have kind of slid our forecast out around six to nine months in terms of what we think the recovery cycle looks like. And so those adjustments we made and production rates and staffing align with that. In terms of your first part of your question is, what do we expect in terms of fourth quarter deliveries? We're not putting exact number out there, but it will certainly be dramatically higher than what you saw in the third quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter? Even if you didn't take stuff to final production, I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip? Is that how you get
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter? Even if you didn't take stuff to final production, I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip? Is that how you get the bump in Q4?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. It's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, its whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So basica
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. It's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, its whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So basically what we’ve done is slow down the rate in terms of the tag time, if you will, of what we move various models to the factory out. So we've slowed down as opposed to saying we're going to build them out and then stop. So we never, as you know, have perfect alignment in terms of sales to manufacturing core because fourth quarters usually are stronger and you got to kind of build into that. So there's not an exact number. It really is sitting in whip. It's not I'd say, ‘Hey, we've built this many airplanes and sold this many airplanes.’

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year? Perhaps if we lock it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?
componenttext: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year? Perhaps if we lock it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff. And obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way, which is, we for 2010 we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis poi
componenttext: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff. And obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way, which is, we for 2010 we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis point change in discount rate impacts our expense number by about $26 million. And a 50 basis point change in rate of return impacts our expense number by about $20 million. Now, there are lots of other factors that go into it in terms of comp rates over time and other things, but I think kind of that gives you a sense of order of magnitude of the sensitivity of our numbers at least. And we'll do that work as we move into year end. And we'll give you kind of a specific guidance on it when we give the 2011 guidance.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a point of clarification on that. Separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed on December 31, 2009?
componenttext: Just a point of clarification on that. Separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed on December 31, 2009?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. There would have been already some kind of, because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done, there would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis. Yes.
componenttext: Yes. There would have been already some kind of, because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done, there would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis. Yes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations. Having been an MBA myself, the sense I get is, a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further deposits that the
componenttext: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations. Having been an MBA myself, the sense I get is, a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further deposits that they have to make. How far of the way are we through that at this point?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been trying to work this thing out for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing. which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check. On most accounts really
componenttext: We've been trying to work this thing out for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing. which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check. On most accounts really has been dropping pretty significantly, right? So most of the volume, or the number of cancellations, which we had, which were really more in the first, second quarters of this year, which were some of the fleet operators and things like that, I think have mostly flushed their way out. So we have seen a real slowing in terms of the number of individual customers that wait until that next deposit is due and walk away from the aircraft. So are there going to be still some? Absolutely. As we do our forecasts and look at our both production rates and our sales programs, we anticipate that some of those customers who we kind of put in our book as a high-risk customer, more and more of those are actually we're now getting that deposit check. Whereas a year ago, the rate of those that we identified as being at risk was much higher that we're going ahead and switching to a cancellation. So are there still some? Absolutely. But the rate has really slowed down dramatically in that area.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side. Could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year had been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking abo
componenttext: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side. Could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year had been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking about 25 deliveries and you're at four year-to-date?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206, 407 light side. And again that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth individual
componenttext: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206, 407 light side. And again that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth individual. Corporate is still slow, much like you see across the Cessna area. But we have still seen continued strength in the larger helicopters, the oil and gas markets, the emergency medical service markets, the international FMS markets have stayed pretty robust. So the way I see it, is that we'll be probably light to that number. But it will be mostly in the sort of the very small, the very light helicopters. So from a margin perspective, from a revenue -- it's not going to be material. 429 specifically, we shipped four this quarter. We're a little behind where we would like to be just in terms of the time it took to get a lot of the kit certifications done and things like that. But you'll see a lot of deliveries here in the fourth quarter. We'll get to the 25 number? Probably not, but it's going to get pretty close. Again, the backlog is there. The people, the customers, are there. So I still feel pretty good when you look at our forecast of 25 this year, 50 next year, which is kind of what our production rate was aimed at, I still think we're going to be pretty much on that 75 for the two years. And again, we'll get -- I don't think we'll get to 25, but we'll get pretty close to it this year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last one. Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilized in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?
componenttext: And last one. Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilized in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we had previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss
componenttext: No. Not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we had previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss activity. I'd say, kind of overall, we are tracking very much kind of within the framework that we've talked about in terms of adequacy of capital and cash conversion levels that kind of continue to support the overall framework of the liquidation schedule. But we haven't gone through the 2011 planning process, specifically for TFC, and a lot of a loss realization will depend on the liquidation strategy that takes place through that period.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type? If you're seeing any variances there? And who's particularly responsible for this pushout
componenttext: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type? If you're seeing any variances there? And who's particularly responsible for this pushout by six to nine months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we look at the last six months it was kind of across the board, right? When the European thing hit, and the impact of the euro was I think pushed a lot of customers away. But with the ripple effect into the U.S. we really saw all the mark
componenttext: Well, I think as we look at the last six months it was kind of across the board, right? When the European thing hit, and the impact of the euro was I think pushed a lot of customers away. But with the ripple effect into the U.S. we really saw all the markets around the world shut down pretty significantly. Latin America was an exception. That still was doing okay. And some Asia Pacific was doing okay. But it was pretty much across the board. It was not all that localized. Now, as we see things coming back, I mean right now I would say we're probably getting more interest and more customer demand internationally than U.S. I think part of that is a lot of U.S. customers are sort of sitting on the sidelines saying, ‘Well, if I'm going to go, I'd like to have some certainty and understanding around things like the bonus depreciation plan,’ and whatnot. So hopefully that will move some of these guys. We know it's already moved a few of them kind of off the sideline and are going ahead and proceeding. But right now I'd have to say, we've been seeing over the last, sort of September and October time frame, of foreign demand coming back faster than U.S. demand.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation? Given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system, how is pricing on new jets holding up?
componenttext: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation? Given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system, how is pricing on new jets holding up?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And the used is still there. I mean, we're stable this last quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment. But
componenttext: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And the used is still there. I mean, we're stable this last quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment. But it's deal by deal, Rob, as you can imagine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?
componenttext: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with size of
componenttext: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with size of the business. And in general, just driving base cost productivity. Our activities and things like ramping up our Mexico operation actually are going very well on both the Cessna and the Bell side. I was down there with a bunch of the team just a few weeks ago and that's ramping up very quickly. So I think we're in a pretty good position here, that as volume comes back and we need to meet some of these requirements, capacity requirements that we're going to have a better cost base than we've had in the past. The other thing I would mention, which obviously here in the quarter we did finalize negotiations with our union in Wichita. I think it was a good outcome in terms of both the company and the employees. It's a seven-year deal, which is great. It lets us get that behind us and focus on just getting the job done here for the next seven years. And we feel pretty good about where it was. Obviously our employees agree to take sort of more of their share of the healthcare costs on a go-forward basis. And I think in terms of economics we all recognize where the industry is and where it's going to be here in the near term going forward and put together a financial package that in the end was acceptable to both the company and the union.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any re
componenttext: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any reasons that you're worried can be sticky through the entire cycle that could kind of cause a muted demand recovery? Whether it be that it's just a generally ‘do more with less environment.’ or it's unused inventory? Whatever it may be?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Noah, obviously it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers though you talk to, and I guess let me just couch it by saying a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show. Folks that I interact with
componenttext: Noah, obviously it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers though you talk to, and I guess let me just couch it by saying a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show. Folks that I interact with on an occasional basis. They are Cessna customers, right? They're flying our aircraft. And so this is kind of a core customer base, if you will, that does refresh their fleets on a fairly regular basis. This is what they're talking, right? The fact that they're now a year or two years, some of them going three years, beyond what they would normally do in terms of refreshing and updating their aircraft. So I think these are people that are without a doubt going to do it. The question of the timing is obviously a little bit uncertain, but it's going to happen. The growth I think as we've talked to international customers, the desire, the demand to have business aircraft and the productivity that they're utilized for. You hear all those same things that you've always heard. I'm pleased that the politics side of it has certainly seemed to have died out. People aren't afraid of, ‘Geeze, will I be viewed as a bad guy because we have corporate aircrafts?’ I mean, that seems to be subsiding a little bit, which is also encouraging. So I guess the bottom line though is you don't hear customers talking about things, or feel things out there that says that there's a fundamental change in the utility or the rationale for why you have a business jet. It's all much more built around the confidence of knowing that their businesses are in a stable spot. They're going to grow. They're going to get back to the normal world. And they're going to go about their business, which includes either buying business jets or refreshing their existing fleets.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer. And we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your lat
componenttext: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer. And we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your latest internal view of what Embraer is working on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think if your NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, at price levels that have been negotiated in a good market. And you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for an aircraft that you're n
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think if your NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, at price levels that have been negotiated in a good market. And you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for an aircraft that you're not going to turn around and sell to fractional customers until 2013, '14, '15, or so. So I think they're pretty sharp. They took advantage of a very down market and went out and tried to drive a very, very aggressive campaign that probably gave them some very favorable, I would say definitely very favorable, pricing. And get that locked in and not have to take the delivery for several years out. So I think it’s pretty sharp on their part. Now from our perspective, I think first of all, I don't think anybody should be surprised to be seeing NetJets offering as part of their suite of aircraft to customers, Embraers. They've had Cessna. They've had Hawker. They've had Gulfstream. So I mean, if you look at their role as kind of a reseller of aircraft in the fractional market, it shouldn't be a surprise again if they're going to carry a pretty broad range of aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Doug Wilburne. Ple
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Textron Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Doug Wilburne. Please go ahead.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our S
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg, and good morning, everyone. Before we begin, I'd like to mention we will be discussing future estimates and expectations during our call today. These forward-looking statements are subject to various risk factors, which are detailed in our SEC filings and also in today's press release.
On the call today, we have Scott Donnelly, Textron's Chairman and CEO; and Frank Connor, our Chief Financial Officer. We're originating today's call from the National Business Aviation Association Conference in Atlanta, as Scott and Frank are here meeting with customers and industry participants. Our customary earnings call presentation can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
Moving now to third quarter results, which appear on Slide 3 of the presentation. Revenues in the quarter were $2.5 billion, down 2.7% from a year ago, which yielded a GAAP loss per share from continuing operations of $0.17. This compares to income of $0.02 per share a year ago. 
During the quarter, we recorded $0.30 in special charges. $0.25 of this amount related to the wind down of TFC's Canadian operation, which we discussed on our second quarter call. This noncash charge eliminated the balance of a cumulative currency translation account, which was triggered because TFC's Canadian operation reached a substantially liquidated basis during the quarter. The remaining $0.05 of special charges was related to restructuring cost. Third quarter earnings from continuing operations, excluding these charges, were $0.13 per share compared to $0.12 a year ago. 
Manufacturing operations generated $157 million in free cash flow during the quarter, bringing the year-to-date amount to $174 million, which compares to last year's nine-month cash flow of $68 million. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everyone. Since we're all here at NBAA, let me just reflect briefly on the mood of the show. I would say that, generally speaking, customers appear to be more optimistic and positive than they were a year ago at the show. Many
componenttext:
Thanks, Doug. Good morning, everyone. Since we're all here at NBAA, let me just reflect briefly on the mood of the show. I would say that, generally speaking, customers appear to be more optimistic and positive than they were a year ago at the show. Many customers, as you talk to them, are reaching a point now where they're a year or two beyond where their normal replacement and upgrade cycle would be. So I think we have a fair number of customers that are genuinely looking at getting back into the market.
And so while I'll tell you it's probably too early to conclude whether this really will be a turning point in the business jet order environment. We are encouraged by the level of customer interest. The recently passed U.S. bonus depreciation bill is certainly a positive factor, and we'll see how much this helps to drive sales. As we all know, new product announcements also stimulate demand in the business jet market. 
In that regard, we unveiled our new Citation Ten aircraft earlier this week and is generating significant attention at the show. The new Ten is a real remarkable aircraft with attractive new features, which we believe will reinvigorate demand for this unique and capable jet. The new Ten will be 15-inches longer and equipped with a set of new Rolls-Royce engines, so it would be more powerful and efficient. As a result, the Ten will be able to fly farther and faster and with more payload. Other features include new winglets, the entirely new Garmin 5000 [G5000] avionics suite, a redesigned cabin with new interiors  and cabin appointments, a new fiber optic-based cabin management system, including the latest interface options for greater in-flight productivity and connectivity.
We're particularly excited about the advanced technology incorporated with this special aircraft and the improved performance characteristics that will give our customers a more efficient and productive aircraft and cabin that are designed to meet the demand and requirements of business travel.
So as we move back to the industry conditions, as we discussed on our last call, order activity in the business jet market slowed in June, and we did not see activity recovering into July or August. In September, activity did pick up somewhat, as you would normally expect, and we ended the quarter with new order value exceeding the value with cancellations, although our book to bill did remain below one. 
On the delivery front, we shipped 26 jets compared to 68 a year ago. With this continued weakness in the demand environment, last month, we announced headcount and production cuts as we seek to reduce overhead cost and reduce our production build rates at Cessna.
On the other hand, leading indicators are improving or at least remaining stable. For example, average daily utilization rate increased to 0.69 hours from 0.68 in the second quarter and 0.66 in the first quarter. This is the highest level we've seen since December of 2008. Also, the FAA [Federal Aviation Administration] rolling three-month average for takeoff and landings were up in both July and August. As a result, Cessna's aftermarket revenues were also up in the quarter, 11% on a year-over-year basis. Previously owned Citations available for sale remained flat at 15.1%. 
With respect to our outlook for the fourth quarter, we expect a significant increase in deliveries from the third quarter, the vast majority of which are already in our backlog. As a result, Cessna should return to profitability in the fourth quarter.
In the Industrial segment, revenues were up nearly 15% as auto, turf care and tool sales remained resilient through the summer months. In fact our organic growth at Industrial for the quarter was over 18%. Looking to the fourth quarter, we believe the year-over-year growth rate in Industrial will continue but to a more moderate rate as we run into more traditional comparisons. 
At E-Z-GO, we've been working to expand our presence in the consumer industrial vehicle market. Last week, we agreed to purchase an electric 4x4 hunting and outdoor recreation vehicle product line, which adds to our specialty vehicle line and expands our distribution reach in that segment.
Moving to the Finance segment. We had another good quarter of liquidations. If you look at Slide 4 in the presentations, you can see that we reduced managed receivables less $627 million. This brings total reduction since the beginning of 2009 to $5.8 billion. Distribution and Finance was the largest area of reduction at $280 million and $75 million liquidations was generated from our Timeshare business as about 50% of that portfolio is now in the amortizing phase. As we look to the full year, we're targeting a total liquidation of $2.4 billion, which will bring us to a two-year reduction of nearly $6.2 billion. 
On Slide 5, you can see cash conversion came in at 94% for the quarter, bringing our year-to-date rate to 92%. We expect the liquidation pace and cash conversion rates will decrease going forward as most of the high turnover, high conversion assets, namely those in our Distribution and Finance and asset-based Lending businesses have been substantially liquidated. In terms of credit performance, we saw a reduction in 60-day delinquencies from $385 million to $357 million, while non-accruals were flat at $876 million. 
While this trend is encouraging and reflects improvement in the general credit market, we do project the 60-day delinquencies will go up in the fourth quarter as a couple of large Timeshare accounts, which are already classified as non-accrual are expected to become delinquent. Charge-offs in the quarter were $26 million, down from $57 million in the second quarter.
Moving to Textron Systems. Revenues were down sequentially primarily related to the timing of international SFW shipments. We expect fourth quarter revenues will benefit from another significant SFW shipment, similar to what occurred in the second quarter. Because customer acceptance with deliveries on international contracts like this one is often done on a lot basis, we do expect we will see some lumpiness in the revenue in this area.
Backlog was essentially flat at $1.6 billion. Margins did come down sequentially primarily driven by lower pricing on new U.S. government ASV contracts and lower international sales on SFW shipments. We continue to pursue a diverse set of opportunities both domestically and internationally. For example, we recently won a contract to provide ground control stations for the U.S. Army's Long Endurance Multi-Intelligence Vehicle, the LEMV program.
Wrapping up with Bell. We had a good quarter, both in terms of top line growth and operational execution. On the military side, we delivered seven V-22s and five H-1s. Performance on both programs continues to improve as we ramp-up production. This benefited our profit margins for the quarter as we recorded positive program adjustments reflecting this trend. On the H-1 program, the attack version, also known as the Super Cobra, was declared operationally effective and suitable, and we expect to have a full rate production decision next month. 
Moving to the Commercial side of the business. We delivered 24 units, including four of our new 429 model. We continue to see significant customer activity and interest in Bell products. For example, there was clearly high interest last week at the Air Medical Transport Conference, where we booked orders for 32 new helicopters from three of the largest medical transport service providers in the industry, with a potential for additional opportunities from these and other customers. Our 429 program is progressing with customer demonstrations around the world generating new orders. In fact, we're pleased we have signed our first 429 customer in the People's Republic of China. So the overall outlook at Bell this year beyond is strong in both our Commercial and Military businesses.
So to sum up the quarter, we think our results again demonstrate the earnings power of the company, despite continued weakness in the business jet market. As we indicated on our second quarter call, a positive business jet order trend appear to be emerging earlier this year. However, that trend stalled to June moving the market’s recovery to the right, in my of view, probably about six to nine months from what we would have anticipated.
Bonus depreciation and some stability in global economic expansion should provide a more positive environment for increased order activity going forward. Our Systems business continues to execute on its programs. We'll pursue several significant international opportunities. Our Industrial businesses continue to perform well as our markets recover. Bell is successfully executing its military programs, and we're seeing increased activity in the commercial sector, which should lead to solid growth over this foreseeable future. And at Finance, we've made excellent progress liquidating receivables. The cash we've generated has allowed us to make substantial improvements in our capital structure. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Frank to provide some financial details for the quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Now turning to Slide 8, let's examine the factors that drove results in the quarter, which yielded a $0.01 year-over-year increase in EPS before special items. Inflation came in at a 2.3% rate, which reduced ea
componenttext:
Thanks, Scott, and good morning, everyone. Now turning to Slide 8, let's examine the factors that drove results in the quarter, which yielded a $0.01 year-over-year increase in EPS before special items. 
Inflation came in at a 2.3% rate, which reduced earnings by $0.12 per share in the quarter, while positive pricing of 0.7% provided a $0.04 benefit. The combined impact of volume and mix cost $0.11 per share. Increased pension expense was $0.04 a share. Our restructuring and execution focus netted a cost-performance benefit of $0.20 per share. TFC's reduced losses benefited the quarter by $0.03. And interest expense, taxes and other miscellaneous items collectedly provided $0.01 per share.
Now starting with Cessna, let's look at the results for each of the business segments. Cessna's revenues decreased $290 million in the third quarter, reflecting lower deliveries. These decreases partially offset by higher aftermarket revenues, which were up about 11.5%. Segment profit decreased $63 million due to lower deliveries, partially offset by lower expenses. These performance benefits were somewhat offset by lower deposit forfeiture income as a result of fewer order cancellations. Cessna backlog ended the third quarter at $3.4 billion, down $321 million from the end of the second quarter.
Turning to Bell. Revenues increased $197 million in the third quarter. U.S. government revenues increased $172 million due to higher V-22 and H-1 deliveries. Commercial revenues increased $25 million due to higher aftermarket volume, improved pricing and favorable mix. Segment profit increased $28 million due to higher overall volume and favorable program adjustments based on improved operational performance. These were partially offset by a gain on a foreign currency exchange contract recorded in 2009, higher research and development cost and higher selling and administrative expenses. Bell backlog decreased $537 million from the end of the second quarter to $6.5 billion.
Moving to Textron Systems. Revenues decreased $42 million, primarily due to lower volume. Segment profit decreased $18 million due to the lower volume, pricing and unfavorable mix. Textron Systems' backlog at the end of the third quarter was $1.6 billion, essentially flat with the end of the second quarter.
At Industrial, revenues increased $77 million due to higher volume, partially offset by an unfavorable foreign exchange impact. Segment profit increased $31 million due to higher volume and improved cost performance, partially offset by higher inflation.
At Finance, consistent with our ongoing liquidation of the non-captive business, segment revenues decreased $12 million. Finance segment loss improved to $13 million, reflecting lower net portfolio losses, loan loss provisions and selling and administrative expenses, partially offset by the impact of lower average finance receivables, lower accretion from previous mark-to-market adjustments and a higher interest rate on debt and a non-recurrence of gains on debt extinguishment.
Now moving to a few corporate items. Corporate expenses were $35 million, down $8 million from a year ago, primarily reflecting lower corporate headcount. One quick comment on special charges. Looking at Slide 9, as you can see, we are still estimating full year special charges of about $0.40 per share. However, the mix has changed slightly. The Canadian currency translation adjustment that we recorded this quarter was less than our previous estimate due to changes in the exchange rate, and we are now projecting some additional restructuring cost associated with our downsizing activities.
With respect to our balance sheet, as announced last month, we repaid the remainder of Textron's bank line in the third quarter, and we now expect to begin to repay the TFC bank line beginning in the fourth quarter. Our consolidated net debt balance is now $5.4 billion, and we expect to reduce it further by the end of the year.
Turning to our outlook on Slide 10. During the fourth quarter, we expect a few non-recurring international tax-related items that will benefit income by about $0.08 per share. The exact amount will depend upon prevailing exchange rates. Including this impact, our full year 2010 outlook for EPS from continuing operations before special charges is now expected to be $0.70 to $0.75 a share. Our free cash flow for manufacturing operations outlook for the year is at least $400 million.
That concludes our prepared remarks for today. Greg, we're now ready to take questions.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And first to the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And first to the line of Cai Von Rumohr with Cowen and Company.

componenttextpreview: So at Cessna, can you tell us, were the forfeitures offset by used aircraft losses? And was the R&D up from the second quarter?
componenttext: So at Cessna, can you tell us, were the forfeitures offset by used aircraft losses? And was the R&D up from the second quarter?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cai, we had a little bit higher residual value write-off than we had deposit forfeitures because the cancellation rates have been down. So we didn't have a lot that went into the forfeitures, but we did have some adjustments across the whole balance of po
componenttext: Cai, we had a little bit higher residual value write-off than we had deposit forfeitures because the cancellation rates have been down. So we didn't have a lot that went into the forfeitures, but we did have some adjustments across the whole balance of portfolio in terms of used aircraft that we did some residual write-downs. But it netted, Cai, in the order of a few million dollars, it's not a big number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I know you announced the Citation Ten. Can you comment? It looks like that's a relatively modest upgrade? The cabin -- while it's longer, it's not wider. Do you have any other -- can you comment at all on other new products that we might look for over
componenttext: And I know you announced the Citation Ten. Can you comment? It looks like that's a relatively modest upgrade? The cabin -- while it's longer, it's not wider. Do you have any other -- can you comment at all on other new products that we might look for over the next 12 months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let me first say that the -- I mean, the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior as well as the winglets and things like that, has actuall
componenttext: Sure. Well, let me first say that the -- I mean, the Citation Ten is a pretty unique aircraft and always has been. 15-inch stretch, a brand-new cockpit and the dramatic refresh in both the interior as well as the winglets and things like that, has actually been -- it's a pretty major makeover to the aircraft and customer response has been very strong to it. So I mean they're pretty impressed with it. But the issue -- that I can also address around other new products is clearly, we have a number of things in the pipeline that are other pretty significant refreshes, as well as some clean-sheet aircraft. And we'll be announcing those kind of sort of as we kind of go from show to show here over the next 18 months to two years as these programs are getting closer to launch, and we're confident that it's the right time in terms of market receptivity to announce it. So the Ten, we have not done an upgrade to that program really almost ever. So it was really time to do it, and that's why that's the first one that we've announced out of the gate. But clearly, there are others that are in there and we'll make those announcements as the time is appropriate at ensuing shows.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeff Sprague from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit
componenttext: Just a couple of things on Cessna first. Scott, can you give us some indication of the bump in deliveries that we should expect into Q4? And I guess, more importantly, the essence of my question is just managing production and the factory here as you exit '10 to prepare yourself for whatever '11 is, you're probably not prepared to give us '11 guidance here on the call. But trying to think about loading the factory here at year end and the throughput in the factory and what that implies for next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jeff. So we have made, as you probably saw the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago, and what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventory, the rate at which we've been building this
componenttext: Sure, Jeff. So we have made, as you probably saw the announcements in terms of reductions in staff at Cessna a couple of weeks ago, and what we did when we took that into consideration was look at the inventory, the rate at which we've been building this year, what we forecast in terms of deliveries for the fourth quarter this year, as well as our kind of first estimate is what we think the deliveries will look like for 2011 and adjust the production rate so that we think we have the right rate now moving through the balance of the year. Now this is not the first time we've told you this, right? I mean, we've done this before. But as I said earlier, I think the reality of given what happened in sort of that May-June time frame, at least up through now, we basically have kind of slid our forecast out around six to nine months in terms of what we think the recovery cycle looks like. And so those adjustments we made at production rates and staffing aligned with that. In terms of your first part of your question is, what do we expect in terms of fourth quarter deliveries? We're not putting an exact number out there, but it will certainly be dramatically higher than what you saw in the third quarter.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter even if you didn't take stuff to final production? I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip. Is that how you get t
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of a sense then around that, how big the delta between production and deliveries were in the quarter even if you didn't take stuff to final production? I would imagine there's maybe some significant whip. Is that how you get the bump in Q4?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. And it's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, it's whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So w
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. And it's hard for me to give you an exact number because it really is, as you said, it's whip, right? I mean, there's very few things where we've taken all the way through the finishing center, completion and do the whole nine yards. So we basically, we've done a slow down. The rate in terms of the takt time, if you will, of what we move various models to the factory out. So we've slowed down as opposed to saying we're going to build them out and then stop. So I mean, we never, as you know, have perfect alignment in terms of sales to manufacturing core because fourth quarter is usually our stronger and you got to kind of build into that. So there's not an exact number. It really is sitting at whip. It's not I'd say, "hey there's -- we built as many airplanes and sold as many airplanes".

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year, perhaps if we locked it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?
componenttext: And lastly, and I'll pass it. Frank, I was wondering if you could give us some early read on how to think about pension for next year, perhaps if we locked it down on today's returns and where we're sitting on current discount rates?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff, and obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way which is, we for 2010, we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis poi
componenttext: Yes, we don't do that work finally until year end, Jeff, and obviously things can happen between now and then. I guess I'd characterize it this way which is, we for 2010, we're using a discount rate of 6 1/4% and a rate of return of 8 1/2%. A 50 basis point change in discount rate impacts our expense number by about $26 million and a 50 basis point change in rate of return impacts our expense number by about $20 million. Now there are lots of other factors that go into it in terms of comp rates over time and other things, but I think kind of that gives you a sense of order of magnitude of the sensitivity of our numbers at least. And we'll do that work as we move into year end, and we'll give you kind of a specific guidance on it when we give the 2011 guidance.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a point of clarification on that. Separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed that 12/31/09?
componenttext: Just a point of clarification on that. Separate from those changes and inputs, is there already some embedded headwind on '11 based on where you closed that 12/31/09?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there would have been already some, kind of because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done. There would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis, yes.
componenttext: Yes, there would have been already some, kind of because of the averaging impact of just the way the calculations are done. There would have already been some embedded headwind in the analysis, yes.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss from UBS.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations, I haven't been down in the NBAA myself, the sense I get is a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further depos
componenttext: Scott, in terms of thinking about the potential for future cancellations, I haven't been down in the NBAA myself, the sense I get is a fair amount of customers still in the backlog are waiting to potentially cancel until they bump up against further deposits that they have to make. How far of the way are we through that at this point?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've been trying to work this thing now for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing, which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check on most accounts really h
componenttext: We've been trying to work this thing now for a couple of years. But I would say the rate of that phenomenon, which you're describing, which is absolutely right. I mean, usually people cancel when it comes to write that next check on most accounts really has been dropping pretty significantly, right? So most of the volume or the number of cancellations which we have, which are really more in the first, second quarters of this year, which were some of the fleet operators, things like that, I think mostly flushed their way out. So we have seen a real slowing in terms of the number of individual customers that wait until that next deposit is due and walk away from the aircraft. So are there going to be still some? Absolutely. As we do our forecast and look at our, both production rates and our sales programs, we anticipate that some of those customers where we kind of put in our book is a high-risk customer, more and more of those are actually -- we're now getting that deposit check. Whereas a year ago, the rate of those that we identified as being at risk was much higher that we're going ahead and switch into a cancellation. So are there still some? Absolutely. But the rate has really slowed down dramatically in that area.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side, could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year have been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then, specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking a
componenttext: And then at Bell, on the Commercial side, could you give us an idea what you're seeing there? I think your delivery guidance for the year have been around 150, going down to 49 year-to-date. And then, specifically on the 429, I think you've been talking about 25 deliveries and you're at four year-to-date?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206 and 407 light side. And again, that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth indivi
componenttext: Sure. So I think with respect to the 150 number, David, I think we're going to be light on that. But I think it's going to be principally in the 206 and 407 light side. And again, that's driven primarily by the market in terms of the high net worth individual corporate is still slow, much like you see across the Cessna area. But we have still seen continued strength in the larger helicopters, the oil and gas markets, the emergency medical service markets, the international FMS markets have stayed pretty robust. So the way I see it, is that we'll be probably light to that number, but it will be mostly in sort of the very small, the very light helicopters. So from a margin perspective, from a revenue, it's not going to be material. 429 specifically, we shipped four this quarter. We're a little behind where we would like to be just in terms of the time it took to get a lot of the kit certifications done and things like that. But you'll see a lot of deliveries here in the fourth quarter. Will it get to the 25 number? Probably not, but it's going to get pretty close. Again, the backlog is there, the people, the customers are there. So I still feel pretty good when you look at our forecast of 25 this year, 50 next year, which is kind of what our production rate was aimed at. I still think we're going to be pretty much on that 75 for the two years. And again, we'll get -- I don't think we'll get to 25, but we'll get pretty close to it this year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last one, Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilize in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?
componenttext: And last one, Frank, at TFC loss there's kind of stabilize in terms of what's running through the income statement. Any framework you could provide about how to think about what that number might look like in 2011?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss act
componenttext: No, not at this point. We'll include that in the guidance. I think as you know, there's volatility around those losses just as we realized losses that we previously reserved for. And so there's always going to be a lumpiness and volatility to the loss activity. I'd say, kind of overall, we're tracking very much kind of within the framework that we've talked about in terms of adequacy of capital and cash conversion levels that kind of continue to support the overall framework of the liquidation schedule. But we haven't gone through the 2011 planning process, specifically for TFC, and a lot of the loss realization will depend on the liquidation strategy that takes place through that period.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type, if you're seeing any variances there and who's particularly responsible for this pushout b
componenttext: Cessna, again, I'm afraid. I was wondering if you could comment on how the demand situation at Cessna has altered maybe on the geographic front or by customer type, if you're seeing any variances there and who's particularly responsible for this pushout by six to nine months?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as we look at the last six months, it was kind of across the board, when the European thing hit and the impact of the euro was, I think pushed a lot of customers away with the trickle effect into the U.S. So we really saw all the markets aro
componenttext: Well, I think as we look at the last six months, it was kind of across the board, when the European thing hit and the impact of the euro was, I think pushed a lot of customers away with the trickle effect into the U.S. So we really saw all the markets around the world shut down pretty significantly. Latin America was an exception, that still was doing okay, and some Asia Pacific was doing okay. But it was pretty much across the board, it was not all that localized. Now as we see things coming back, I mean right now, I would say we're probably getting more interest and more customer demand internationally than U.S. And I think part of that is a lot of U.S. customers were sort of sitting on the sidelines saying, well, if I'm going to go, I'd like to have some certainty and understanding around things like the bonus depreciation plan and whatnot. So hopefully that will move some of these guys. We know it's already moved a few of them kind of off the sideline and are going ahead and proceeding. But right now, I'd have to say, we've been seeing over the last, sort of September and October time frame foreign demand coming back faster than U.S. demand.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system. How is pricing on new jet toning up?
componenttext: And also, I was wondering if you could comment on the pricing situation given there seems to be a fair amount of inventory in the system. How is pricing on new jet toning up?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And then the used is still there. I mean, we stabled this last quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment.
componenttext: As best it can. It's a very competitive market out there, obviously. And then the used is still there. I mean, we stabled this last quarter, but it's certainly down off of its peak. But there's no question that it's still a difficult pricing environment. But it's deal by deal, Rob, as you can imagine.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?
componenttext: And just finally on Cessna, I was wondering if you can give us an update on how your restructuring is going there and your efforts to reduce your cost base?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with the siz
componenttext: Pretty well. I mean, unfortunately, we just went through another set of cost reductions, although I would say probably half of that was directly volume related. The other half was continuing to make sure that we get our cost structure aligned with the size of the business, and in general, just driving base cost productivity. Our activities and things like ramping up our Mexico operation actually are going very well on both the Cessna and the Bell side. I was down there with a bunch of the team just a few weeks ago and that's ramping up very quickly. So I think we're in a pretty good position here, that as volume comes back and we need to meet some of these requirements, capacity requirements that we're going to have a better cost base than we've had in the past. The other thing I would mention, which obviously here in the quarter we did finalize negotiations with our union in Wichita. I think it was a good outcome in terms of both the company and the employees. It's a seven-year deal which is great, and let's just get that behind us and focus on just getting the job done here for the next seven years. And we feel pretty good about where it was, obviously our employees agree to take sort of more of their share of the healthcare cost on a go-forward basis. And I think in terms of economics, we all recognize where the industry is and where it's going to be here in the near term going forward and put together a financial package that in the end was acceptable to both the company and the union.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Poponak from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any re
componenttext: I guess it can be challenging to predict the exact timing of when business jet demand comes back. But I wonder if you're hearing anything from your customers that you're in conversations with that are deciding not to buy aircraft? If you're hearing any reasons that you're worried can be sticky through the entire cycle that could kind of cause a muted demand recovery, whether it be that it's just a generally do more with less environment or it's a young inventory, a young used inventory or whatever it may be?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Noah, obviously, it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers that you talk to, and I guess let me just -- customer by saying, a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show, folks that I interact wi
componenttext: Noah, obviously, it is hard to predict. I've been particularly not good at predicting it. The customers that you talk to, and I guess let me just -- customer by saying, a lot of these customers are folks that are here at the show, folks that I interact with on occasional basis that are -- they are Cessna customers, right? They're flying our aircraft. And so this is kind of a core, if you will, of a customer base that does refresh their fleets on a fairly regular basis. This is what they're talking, right? The fact that they're now a year or two years, some of them going three years beyond what they would normally do in terms of refreshing and updating their aircraft. So I think these are people that are, without a doubt, going to do it. The question of the timing is obviously a little bit uncertain, but it's going to happen. The growth I think as we've talked to international customers, the desire, the demand to have business aircraft and the productivity that they're utilized for, you hear all those same things that you've always heard. I'm pleased that the politics side of it has certainly seem to have died out. People aren't afraid of, geez, why be viewed as a bad guy because we have corporate aircrafts. I mean, that seems to be subsiding a little bit, which is also encouraging. So I guess the bottom line is you don't hear customers talking about things or feel things out there that says that there's a fundamental change in the utility or the rationale for why you have a business jet. It's all much more built around the confidence of knowing that their businesses are in a stable spot. They're going to grow, they're going to get back to the normal world. And they're going to go about their business, which includes either buying business jets or refreshing their existing fleets.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer, and we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your lat
componenttext: I guess one of the concerns we hear on the pace of the recovery for current players is the emergence of Embraer, and we saw NetJets order there. Why did NetJets jump out of other backlogs, and then into theirs? And then maybe if you can just give your latest internal view of what Embraer is working on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I think if you're NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, price levels that have been negotiated in a good market and you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for aircraft that you're not go
componenttext: Sure. Well, I think if you're NetJets, it's a pretty smart move, right? So you had backlogs of aircrafts, price levels that have been negotiated in a good market and you negotiate at the bottom of the trough for new pricing for aircraft that you're not going to turn around and sell to fractional customers until 2013, '14, '15 or so. So I think they're pretty sharp. They took advantage of a very down market and went out and tried to drive a very, very aggressive campaign that probably gave them some very favorable, I would say definitely very favorable pricing and get that locked in and not have to take delivery for several years out. So I think pretty sharp on their part. Now from our perspective, I think first of all, I don't think anybody should be surprised seeing NetJets offering as part of their suite of aircraft to customers, Embraers. They've had Cessna, they've had Hawker, Gulfstream. So I mean, if you look at their role it's kind of a reseller of aircraft in the fractional market. It shouldn't be a surprise again if they're going to carry a pretty broad range of aircraft.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there any update on the potential and timing for a second multi-year in V-22?
componenttext: And is there any update on the potential and timing for a second multi-year in V-22?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, negotiations and discussions with the customer have already started along that exact line.
componenttext: Absolutely, negotiations and discussions with the customer have already started along that exact line.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any sense on timing?
componenttext: And any sense on timing?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean the current multi-year goes out through deliveries to 2014. So I don't know exactly, Noah, what they're talking about. But I would say in the next year or so, it's probably when they want to get that definitize and nailed down.
componenttext: Well, I mean the current multi-year goes out through deliveries to 2014. So I don't know exactly, Noah, what they're talking about. But I would say in the next year or so, it's probably when they want to get that definitize and nailed down.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Skibitski from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Skibitski from SunTrust.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: Not sure if you said this or not, but can you quantify for us the deposit forfeiture income this quarter at Cessna versus Q2?
