componenttext: Not sure if you said this or not, but can you quantify for us the deposit forfeiture income this quarter at Cessna versus Q2?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we said is that the net of the deposit and the used valuation was a negative couple of million dollars.
componenttext: What we said is that the net of the deposit and the used valuation was a negative couple of million dollars.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about on the one-time gain in Bell? Can you quantify that and tell us what programs they were on?
componenttext: How about on the one-time gain in Bell? Can you quantify that and tell us what programs they were on?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it related to the overall kind of rate structure at Bell and just benefiting on the cost front from improving performance and leveraging the volumes that are going through Bell. It benefits the quarter by about a couple of hundred basis points. So w
componenttext: Well, it related to the overall kind of rate structure at Bell and just benefiting on the cost front from improving performance and leveraging the volumes that are going through Bell. It benefits the quarter by about a couple of hundred basis points. So we typically have said Bell should be in the 11-ish percent area on kind of a run rate basis. And obviously, we were up at the 13% area for this quarter, and that 200 basis points was kind of this performance improvement.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So not necessarily one specific program?
componenttext: So not necessarily one specific program?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, it's really kind of across the entirety of the base.
componenttext: No, it's really kind of across the entirety of the base.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, would you mind updating us on international opportunities for ASV in Shadow? I think I saw a couple notifications this quarter, I'm just wondering if there's anything else out there in the works?
componenttext: And then, would you mind updating us on international opportunities for ASV in Shadow? I think I saw a couple notifications this quarter, I'm just wondering if there's anything else out there in the works?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there are. I mean, Shadow, we've announced a couple. There's a couple that are still in negotiations and things we're chasing after. The same with ASV, probably the most notable international which we have talked about before is the Canadian Tap D [
componenttext: Well, there are. I mean, Shadow, we've announced a couple. There's a couple that are still in negotiations and things we're chasing after. The same with ASV, probably the most notable international which we have talked about before is the Canadian Tap D [ph] program. That decision is probably still a year or so away, but there are also a number of other international that we haven't talked about yet, which are still sort of in the negotiation phase, which we're hopeful we would get close here on the next six month or so.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Tusa from JPMorgan.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just following on that Bell question, and then moving on to D&I, same kind of question with Systems. The longer-term margin there, kind of ticked down as you guys would have expected and maybe a little bit more than we would have expected in the quarter.
componenttext: Just following on that Bell question, and then moving on to D&I, same kind of question with Systems. The longer-term margin there, kind of ticked down as you guys would have expected and maybe a little bit more than we would have expected in the quarter. What is kind of a more normal kind of longer-term margin we can think of at the Defense business?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I still think the Systems business is one, Steve, that we've talked about being kind of in that 11% sort of range. I think we're still -- we still feel like that's about where it's going to be. The margin rates didn't tick down. Now when we talk abo
componenttext: Well, I still think the Systems business is one, Steve, that we've talked about being kind of in that 11% sort of range. I think we're still -- we still feel like that's about where it's going to be. The margin rates didn't tick down. Now when we talk about the fact that we did have two big chunks of business in both the ASVs and the UAVs that were very high margin businesses. We got renegotiated as you would expect and that's kind of what brought us down to those margin rates that we are -- where we are now. I think there was a little bit of a challenge in the quarters because the nature of these SFW contracts, because there's some quarters we're going to have a big sale and associated margins, other quarters where you'll probably going to have zero on SFW just because of how the lot acceptance works out. But I would say that, I think those are the kind -- we don't feel differently about those margin rates than the previous guidance that we gave you, and I think we'll hang in that area.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the longer term kind of normalized margin for Bell and D&I both kind of in that low double digit range?
componenttext: So the longer term kind of normalized margin for Bell and D&I both kind of in that low double digit range?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. The only thing that has changed, Steve, that they are putting some more pressure on those numbers, and obviously we're doing other things to try to make it up. What we talked about a little bit earlier, these pension headwinds are tough in terms
componenttext: Exactly. The only thing that has changed, Steve, that they are putting some more pressure on those numbers, and obviously we're doing other things to try to make it up. What we talked about a little bit earlier, these pension headwinds are tough in terms of both earnings and obviously cash contributions ultimately we'll need to make.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would those margins be down in 2011?
componenttext: Would those margins be down in 2011?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There will be more pressure on the pension side, and so the issue for us, of course, is the challenge of trying to go drive other means of productivity to try to compensate for them, but they are pressure points for sure.
componenttext: There will be more pressure on the pension side, and so the issue for us, of course, is the challenge of trying to go drive other means of productivity to try to compensate for them, but they are pressure points for sure.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on Cessna, you had a real kind of a drying up of activity in the summer. Do you feel the market is still that sensitive? So that if the euro moves like it did back then or if we had another little gyration here in the macro environment, are
componenttext: And then just on Cessna, you had a real kind of a drying up of activity in the summer. Do you feel the market is still that sensitive? So that if the euro moves like it did back then or if we had another little gyration here in the macro environment, are people still sensitive? Do you feel like, I mean, so for every 10% to 15% move in the S&P 500, do we push out another six to nine months? Or have people kind of come to a resolution on how comfortable they feel in their financial situation that, that was kind of the last bit of pressure on the mentality of the customer? What's your sense there?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, I still think this has an awful lot to do with confidence. And I think what happened, coming out of the spring, was there was a lack of confidence in the recovery. And when that happens, people, consumers and businesses kind of quit spending money.
componenttext: Steve, I still think this has an awful lot to do with confidence. And I think what happened, coming out of the spring, was there was a lack of confidence in the recovery. And when that happens, people, consumers and businesses kind of quit spending money. In other words, just airplanes, right? It was any big ticket, capital investments. And I think we saw that across most of industry, certainly in the U.S. and around most of the world. So I don't think we're immune to that. I think people have gotten -- it appears people have gotten a little more comfortable that the recovery stumbled, but it didn't go into the so-called double dip and that's now bringing a little bit of confidence back that people can move on. But I think if you have another European debt crisis, if you have something of that magnitude, I mean I think there's no doubt our industry is still susceptible to those kinds of things, derailing the economic recovery and more specifically, the business jet recovery.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the margin at Cessna, would you guys expect a relatively significant snap back next year? Actually, you've kind of worked your way through the overproduction of this year. How do we think about the Cessna margin for next year?
componenttext: Just on the margin at Cessna, would you guys expect a relatively significant snap back next year? Actually, you've kind of worked your way through the overproduction of this year. How do we think about the Cessna margin for next year?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, again, Steve, it's all going to be based on what kind of volumes we get out there, right? We still personally feel that we will see better volumes in 2011 than 2010. I mean, I'm sure you read all the various pundits and folks that are kind of well o
componenttext: Well, again, Steve, it's all going to be based on what kind of volumes we get out there, right? We still personally feel that we will see better volumes in 2011 than 2010. I mean, I'm sure you read all the various pundits and folks that are kind of well over the map as to was '10 the trough or is '11 the trough. And look, everybody is guessing, right? I mean, our guess and our sense to talking to customers and whatnot is that we're still expecting to have higher 2011 deliveries than 2010. And obviously, that will translate into better margin rates.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a couple more biz [business] jet questions, sorry about belaboring this stuff. I was down at NBAA as well as probably a bunch of my peers. You really did see a tangible difference between what's going on in the, what's called the Large Jet seg
componenttext: Scott, just a couple more biz [business] jet questions, sorry about belaboring this stuff. I was down at NBAA as well as probably a bunch of my peers. You really did see a tangible difference between what's going on in the, what's called the Large Jet segment and then kind of the mid and light. So kind of my two questions are, one, why do you think that this? What's peculiar about the mids and lights that they're just not being as robust as the large? And then two, the Columbus came, it went. If Cessna were to have a product in that space, I mean, in your view is that the good form of diversification given how you're really seeing some different market dynamics between the different size segment?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first one, I would say, Ron, I mean there's no question that the dynamics out there for the long-haul, big, large-cabin jet market has come back faster than the light to mid-size. And I think you're talking about some different dynamics here in
componenttext: Well, the first one, I would say, Ron, I mean there's no question that the dynamics out there for the long-haul, big, large-cabin jet market has come back faster than the light to mid-size. And I think you're talking about some different dynamics here in terms of who those buyers are. Are they very large corporations or very, very high net worth individuals, families and such that tend to be the customer of that segment. Now the reality is, for the light to mid-size jet market, we do have obviously some fleet operations in pretty big companies. But the bulk of our customers are small, mid-size business people and high net worth individual, not somebody that's the billionaire set. So I think the confidence in that community and that little buyer is more economically sensitive than the multi-billionaire or the huge, multi-national corporation. So I think that's just kind of the life the world we're living in right now is that our typical buyer is more economically sensitive than the real big cabin guys. So that's where this confidence factor comes in, in terms of getting our customers confident to go spend $6 million, $8 million, $15 million, $20 million as opposed to being up there in the $50 million, $60 million kind of transaction that you see on the large cabin guys. And I don't know why that would change, right? I mean, the light and mid will come back when our customer set feels more confidence.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then how about from a product portfolio point of view, I mean down the road, eventually, I mean is it a place Cessna should go to larger and larger aircraft?
componenttext: Then how about from a product portfolio point of view, I mean down the road, eventually, I mean is it a place Cessna should go to larger and larger aircraft?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that the notion to come back, I'm sorry, your question on the Columbus side is that we do have -- if you look at our customer set, that customer set is principally more of a regional customer, right, where there's domestic U.S., domestic Eur
componenttext: Well, I think that the notion to come back, I'm sorry, your question on the Columbus side is that we do have -- if you look at our customer set, that customer set is principally more of a regional customer, right, where there's domestic U.S., domestic Europe, Latin American regions. But that customer does have a need to do some international longer-haul travel. And that's where we were, the Columbus was aimed. So are we thinking about, geez, we should be competing with G550s and globals? No. That's outside of I think what is traditionally our customer set. The Columbus, which we would certainly like to go back to at some point, when the market conditions are right and the light, mid-world has stabilized is a nice add-on in terms of taking care of that customer base because we do have a significant number of them that do have some international needs, longer-haul needs. And we'd like to stay on the Cessna family as opposed to needing to go over to a big Bombardier or a big Gulfstream product.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe just one last question again on the biz jet market. How much of a factor has the availability of financing and financing terms and changing financing terms been in terms of a negative headwind in terms of people finalizing orders?
componenttext: And maybe just one last question again on the biz jet market. How much of a factor has the availability of financing and financing terms and changing financing terms been in terms of a negative headwind in terms of people finalizing orders?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it was a big headwind for a while, but I would say that things have been certainly loosening up. I mean, we've had credit availability for people. We've seen some of the other larger guys historically financing in the biz jet world are coming back i
componenttext: Well, it was a big headwind for a while, but I would say that things have been certainly loosening up. I mean, we've had credit availability for people. We've seen some of the other larger guys historically financing in the biz jet world are coming back into it. The money is clearly available. There is a desire and a need for higher levels of down payment and looking to credit. But I think it's starting to loosen up and it's not as big as an issue as it once was.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Julian Mitchell from Credit Suisse.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One was on the cost structure within Cessna, I guess how you're thinking about the difference between the sort of permanent-fixed cost reduction from the migration of production? And then secondly, how much of your cost reduction is related to your six to
componenttext: One was on the cost structure within Cessna, I guess how you're thinking about the difference between the sort of permanent-fixed cost reduction from the migration of production? And then secondly, how much of your cost reduction is related to your six to nine month push out in terms of the business jet delivery's recovery? And then secondly, as well just on the Industrial business, you've had very high incremental margins there because of a steep revenue bounce back off of a fairly low cost base. I guess, how you're thinking about incremental margins in Industrial exiting this year in terms of adding on capacity or raising R&D and how those affect the incrementals?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, if I go backward through those, I would say that, first of all, on the Industrial side, that margin leverage that we've been seeing associated with the volume, as we think about 2011 and those markets continuing to recover, I think we can continue t
componenttext: Well, if I go backward through those, I would say that, first of all, on the Industrial side, that margin leverage that we've been seeing associated with the volume, as we think about 2011 and those markets continuing to recover, I think we can continue to generate good leverage on those margins. We're certainly, even though revenue and volume has come back, it's still nowhere near back to where it was historically. So in terms of capacity to produce, we're not in a point where we have to start thinking about making any kind of significant capital investments to support further ramp in those businesses. I mean, some tooling here and there, I mean there's obviously some capital. But there's certainly no reason to think about a need to invest a lot of capital in those businesses as they continue to grow because they're still well below the levels at which they historically have seen. At Cessna, the cost, I mean you certainly have a fixed-base cost, let's say in the Wichita in terms of facilities and capability. I think as volume returns, that we can effectively utilize that capacity. I think we have a union contract and a cost base that will allow us to be very competitive in terms of aircraft completions and customizing in interiors and delivery and things like that. But as we talked about before, we still believe and are continuing to restructure in terms of where a lot of the sub-level fabrication and assembly goes along. And that's been our strategy with Mexico, where we have made some significant investments and continue to do that to make sure that we have capacity in that region at a cost that we think would need us to be for us to be competitive going forward. So there's kind of blend here of making sure you're effectively utilizing what you have in place in Wichita, but also expanding capacity in those places where we know we have to have a lower cost labor base.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Levenson from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Here's a non-Cessna question for you. It appears that the Marine Corps is rejiggerring the makeup of their helicopter squadrons? And if you do the arithmetic, it sounds like maybe they're going to come up short some H-1s. Have they come to you? Or do you
componenttext: Here's a non-Cessna question for you. It appears that the Marine Corps is rejiggerring the makeup of their helicopter squadrons? And if you do the arithmetic, it sounds like maybe they're going to come up short some H-1s. Have they come to you? Or do you expect to talk to them about revising that contract higher?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, obviously, we're in conversations with the Marine Aviation folks on a virtually daily basis. I want to be careful to comment specifically about your question, because I haven't had a discussion with them with respect to overall number change
componenttext: Well, I mean, obviously, we're in conversations with the Marine Aviation folks on a virtually daily basis. I want to be careful to comment specifically about your question, because I haven't had a discussion with them with respect to overall number changes. But there are regular discussions around how many utility versus how many Super Cobras. So as they are always looking out, their deployment schedules and what to make up for the squadrons are, how they operate, those are discussions that we have all the time with them. So obviously, anytime they want to add additional aircraft is certainly fine with us, and we're trying to make sure we're doing the right things in terms of the cost per unit to help allow them to do it. We know they always love to have more helicopters. But obviously, they have their own budgetary issues that they got to be careful about it. But sure, we'll work with them in terms of both the mix and the makeup of them and the overall total number.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And last Cessna question. How much investment is likely to be required to do the revision on Citation Ten?
componenttext: And last Cessna question. How much investment is likely to be required to do the revision on Citation Ten?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Pretty modest really, because there's some modest changes to tooling because the fuselage stretch, but the wing is virtually identical. Obviously, there's some minor modifications in the structure with the winglets. There's no tooling change on the engine
componenttext: Pretty modest really, because there's some modest changes to tooling because the fuselage stretch, but the wing is virtually identical. Obviously, there's some minor modifications in the structure with the winglets. There's no tooling change on the engines. It's a redesign on the part of Rolls-Royce for the fan which gives us some better thrust and better efficiencies but does not impact final assembly in terms of tooling. And then of course the cockpit, that adaptation is mostly fabrication work in cable and harnessing. So there's a lot of work, but it's not a capital-intensive change.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Company.

componenttext: A follow up to Jeff's questions on pension. Could you tell us what your return on assets year-to-date is? And what impact the very large layoffs you've had at Cessna would have on your pension expense next year?

componenttext: Well, I mean we're only part way through the year, it's kind of nine months through the year. We're on an annualized basis, we'd be on target. We'll see if it annualizes out to that basis. But on an annualized basis, we'd be on target.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010

componenttext: And of course, as you know, Cai, the actual return on the assets this year has a relatively small impact on what our expense headwind might be next year.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so what's the impact of the layoffs at Cessna? And I guess another question would be, what percent of your expense is in government areas of Bell and Systems?
componenttext: And so what's the impact of the layoffs at Cessna? And I guess another question would be, what percent of your expense is in government areas of Bell and Systems?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Cessna impact will kind of not -- that won't have a meaningful impact. And I don't --  do you...
componenttext: The Cessna impact will kind of not -- that won't have a meaningful impact. And I don't --  do you...

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you're asking about how much is in military, and the bottom line is that we have very little recoverability under the various programs available because we're in fixed price contracts that are already set. So in the immediate term, there's not a tre
componenttext: Well, you're asking about how much is in military, and the bottom line is that we have very little recoverability under the various programs available because we're in fixed price contracts that are already set. So in the immediate term, there's not a tremendous amount of relief that we can garner from our contracts.

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of contributions to your plan, I understand it's pretty modest this year. Where is that likely to go over the next couple of years?
componenttext: And in terms of contributions to your plan, I understand it's pretty modest this year. Where is that likely to go over the next couple of years?

headline: Textron Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean it's going to increase kind of it will depend ultimately on kind of what these calculations look like. But it's going to be up in the $200 million, $300 million-type level. Now obviously, a lot of this gets impacted by -- we're in a very, very
componenttext: Yes, I mean it's going to increase kind of it will depend ultimately on kind of what these calculations look like. But it's going to be up in the $200 million, $300 million-type level. Now obviously, a lot of this gets impacted by -- we're in a very, very low rate environment, right? And so kind of all of this stuff needs to ultimately be looked at in the context of both kind of whatever the rate environment is when you're setting these numbers and then expectations over time. And so for all of this to carry forward into the future, you would have to assume that the same rate environment was going to be maintained into the future, which I think most people would probably think is unlikely, but it certainly will impact the near-term calculations.
